properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain and wind is expected. Total rainfall: 25 to 50 mm, possibly higher near the Fundy coast. Maximum wind gusts: 60 to 80 km/h, possibly higher along the Fundy coast. Locations: western to central New Brunswick. Time span: Monday morning till Tuesday morning. Remarks: Showers will begin Monday morning over southwestern New Brunswick, then spread rapidly across the province in the afternoon. The rain is expected to become heavy at times Monday evening before ending early Tuesday morning. Strong southerly winds and very mild temperatures will accompany the rainfall, resulting in rapid snowmelt. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-13T10:39:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-12T18:40:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1540704093.2020

properties.Title: Update: High Water Warning Continued For The Red River From Emerson To The Red River Floodway Inlet Control Structure
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a High Water Warning on the Red River from Emerson to the Red River Floodway Inlet Control Structure due to high water flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions given by local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca. Follow @MBGov and @MBGovRoads on Twitter or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2020-04-13T11:45:00-05:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2020-04-12T11:58:36-05:00, 27D98D6E-8936-CFE4-027B-E8BD12251A61
Area: Red River from Emerson to the Red River Floodway Inlet Control Structure
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain tonight and Monday and strong winds Monday afternoon into Monday evening. Rain is forecast to begin tonight north of Lake Ontario and will expand into Eastern Ontario by Monday morning. Total rainfall amounts of 25 to 35 mm are expected. The rain will taper off from west to east Monday afternoon into Monday evening. Strong southwesterly winds are also forecast to develop Monday afternoon into Monday evening. Wind gusts up to 80 km/h will be possible. These strong winds will ease Monday night. These winds and rain are associated with a strong low pressure system that is forecast to track across Northeastern Ontario on Monday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-13T01:00:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-12T09:01:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2809274134.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain early this week with 25 millimetres expected A low pressure system from Colorado will reach the province of Quebec and give rain from Monday into Tuesday morning. Heavy rainfall combined with snowmelt may cause flash floods and ponding on roads. Flooding is possible in low lying areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds expected Monday afternoon and evening. Strong southwesterly winds are forecast to develop Monday afternoon and will continue into the evening. Wind gusts up to 90 km/h will be possible, particularly near the shoreline of Georgian Bay. Winds will ease Monday night. These winds are associated with a strong low pressure system that is forecast to track across Northeastern Ontario on Monday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A significant snowfall is expected Monday with the highest amounts near and east of Marathon and lower amounts near Terrace Bay and Schreiber. A low pressure system is forecast to track across Northeastern Ontario Monday bringing snow to the area. Snow is expected to begin tonight before becoming heavy Monday morning. Northerly winds gusting up to 60 km/h are also likely resulting in blowing snow. Snow and local blowing snow will continue Monday before tapering to flurries Monday night. Snowfall amounts near 20 cm are currently expected over eastern sections near Marathon with lesser amounts further west toward Terrace Bay and Schreiber. Snowfall amounts remain somewhat uncertain as a slight shift in the track or strength of this low pressure system will significantly change snowfall accumulations. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-13T07:01:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-12T15:02:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3914879316.2020
Area: Marathon - Schreiber
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A significant snowfall is expected Monday, especially east of Longlac. A low pressure system is forecast to track across Northeastern Ontario Monday bringing snow to the area. Snow is expected to begin late tonight before becoming heavy Monday morning. Northerly winds gusting up to 60 km/h are also likely resulting in blowing snow. Snow and local blowing snow will continue Monday before tapering to flurries Monday night. Total snowfall amounts near 15 cm will be possible in areas east of Longlac. Snowfall amounts remain uncertain as a slight shift in the track or strength of this low pressure system will significantly change snowfall accumulations. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential significant snowfall and rainfall tonight into Monday. A low pressure system is forecast to track across Northeastern Ontario Monday bringing heavy rain and snow to the area. Snow will begin late this evening over areas near Foleyet and Gogama, while rain will begin further south toward Sudbury. The snow will change over to rain on Monday then change back to flurries Monday afternoon or evening. Total snowfall amounts near 15 cm are expected near Foleyet while rainfall amounts of 15 to 25 mm in areas further to the south and east will be possible. Exact snowfall amounts and the position of the rain snow line remain uncertain as a slight shift in the track or strength of this low pressure system will significantly change snow and rainfall amounts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-13T07:33:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-12T15:34:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3175074089.2020
Area: Gogama - Foleyet
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A major winter storm is expected Monday into Monday night. A low pressure system is forecast to track across Northeastern Ontario Monday bringing heavy snow and blowing snow to the area. The snow is expected to begin early Monday morning near Kapuskasing, in the late morning near Moosonee and near noon in Fort Albany. Northerly winds gusting near 60 or 70 km/h are also likely resulting in widespread blowing snow. Snow and blowing snow will continue into Monday night before tapering to flurries on Tuesday. Total snowfall amounts in the 30 to 50 cm range will be possible. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-13T07:22:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-04-12T15:23:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1700811993.2020
Area: Fort Albany, Moosonee
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A major snowfall is expected tonight into Monday. A low pressure system is forecast to track across Northeastern Ontario Monday bringing snow to the area. Snow is expected to begin late this evening before becoming heavy tonight. Snow may mix with or change to rain in areas to the east of Chapleau on Monday. There is also the likelihood of freezing rain Monday morning. Snow is expected to taper to flurries Monday night. Northerly winds gusting near 60 km/h are also likely Monday evening resulting in blowing snow. Total snowfall amounts in the 25 to 40 cm range will be possible with the highest amounts west of Chapleau. Exact snowfall amounts and the position of the rain snow line remain uncertain as a slight shift in the track or strength of this low pressure system will significantly change the snowfall and rainfall amounts. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-13T07:39:06-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain tonight into Monday and strong winds Monday Afternoon. Heavy rain is forecast to begin tonight. The rain will continue into Monday. Total rainfall amounts of 20 to 30 mm will be possible by Monday evening. Strong southwesterly winds are also forecast to develop Monday afternoon into Monday evening. Wind gusts up to 100 km/h will be possible with the strongest winds expected along the shorelines of Lake Ontario and Lake Erie. These strong winds will ease Monday night. These winds and rain are associated with a strong low pressure system that is forecast to track across Northeastern Ontario on Monday. There will be the potential for power outages due to the wind Monday afternoon and evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain tonight into Monday and strong winds Monday afternoon. Rain or snow will begin this evening and then transition to heavy rain tonight. Rain will continue Monday before changing to flurries Monday afternoon or evening. Total rainfall amounts of 20 to 30 mm are expected. Strong westerly winds are also forecast to develop Monday afternoon. Wind gusts of 70 to 90 km/h will be possible with the strongest winds expected along the shorelines of Lake Superior and Lake Huron. Winds will ease Monday night. These strong winds and rain are the result of a strong low pressure system forecast to track across Northeastern Ontario on Monday. Caution is advised near creeks and streams tonight and Monday. Rain and melting snow may also pond on some roads. Some power outages will be possible Monday afternoon and evening in the gusty winds. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-04-13T07:49:02-00:00

properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A developing low over Colorado will intensify as it approaches James Bay early in the week. Snow will begin on Monday, and the storm will then intensify during the evening. A total of 20 to 30 centimetres of snow, strong winds and significant blowing snow giving near-zero visibilities are expected. Conditions will improve overnight Tuesday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Northwest winds with gusts up to 80 km/h combined with falling snow will give reduced visibilities of less than 400 meters to Clyde River. Visibilities are expected to deteriorate later this morning. Winds will gradually diminish on Monday and conditions will improve. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
